results.title: The Moghul emperors
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into India”.
The Moghuls, described by some historians as the most brilliant dynasty of emperors in modern times, ruled India from the 16th century to the middle of the 18th century. Keith Adam visits many of the monuments they created, including the Taj Mahal, and recreates their colourful history.

results.title: The Modern prospector
results.creator_credit: Tim Wilson, ONF | NFB and Jean-Yves Bigras
results.brief_description: Instead of pick and shovel, the modern prospector employs all the resources of science to look for buried treasure. Aerial surveys, airborne magnetometers, instruments to measure the breadth and depth of ore bodies - with these the prospector can provide data to the company geologist to pinpoint the most promising drilling locations.

results.title: The Modern lithographer
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A detailed study of the techniques of lithographic artists, and the process of duplicating black and white originals by means of direct and offset lithography. The roles of the commercial photographer and the modern printing press in the mass production of attractive art prints, including advertising materials, are shown.

results.title: The Modern infantryman
results.brief_description: Illustrates the role of the infantryman in the modern army. Shows his training in the use of weapons and in tactics, illustrates the three types of battle dress adapted to meet the demands of different climates. The weapons shown include the .303 rifle, light and medium machine gun, flame throwers, hand grenades and anti-tank weapons. Today, the infantry has taken to the air and infantrymen are being trained to become members of paratroop units.

results.title: The Modern electric refrigerator. Part 1. The How and why of refrigeration
results.creator_credit: Frank A. Hoare, Merton Park, Film Producers Guild and David Cons
results.brief_description: Describes the nature of food and explains how heat acts to cause decay and cold acts as a preservative. Explains three main processes of refrigeration - evaporation, pressure and condensation, and how these function in a sealed unit. Shows how to pack food for maximum efficiency and air circulation. Gives advice on defrosting, cleaning and care.

results.title: The Moat monster
results.creator_credit: Steve Campus Productions and Sara H Arnaud
results.brief_description: Infantile anxieties embodied in the apocryphal Moat Monster. Extraordinary document of unrestrained play, profiling a small group of pre-school children and the spontaneous generation of their narrative about the ‘Moat Monster’. Contingent nature of children’s reality finds expression in the creative dynamism of this whimsical drama. Portions of this film appear in a full length film entitled ‘Role Enactment in Children’s Play: a Developmental Overview’. Episode 3 of “Training module on role enactment in children’s play” series.

results.title: The Mississippi River: background for social studies
results.brief_description: Follows a houseboat down the Mississippi River, explaining that the river and its tributaries form a vast network of waterways, linking great agricultural and industrial areas with important cities and ports. The importance of the Mississippi as a drainage basin for more than a third of the continent; its geographic, commercial and historic influence on adjacent lands.

results.title: The Missing interest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Office Supervisor’s Problem”.
A dramatised case problem which can lead to searching discussion of methods of developing employee involvement and interest in low level narrow scope jobs. Supervisors can identify and project themselves into the situation. The film poses but does not answer a basic problem.

results.title: The Mirror of paradoxes: self-portraits, Rembrandt Van Rijn
results.creator_credit: Alain Jaubert, Musée du Louvre, Delta Image, FR3 and La Sept
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Palettes”.
Rembrandt created almost one hundred self-portraits from the age of twenty to the age of sixty-three. This program looks at a selection of these in detail, discussing his technique, how it differed from others’ painting at the same time, at some of the possible symbolism of the costumes and props he used and at outside influences on his art. An American version of a French production.
results.title_for_label: The Mirror of paradoxes: self-portraits, Rembrandt Van Rijn
